author: By Edward Wong
title: Biden Urges Congress to Quickly Approve F-16 Sale to Turkey
description: The White House sent a letter to four senior lawmakers, one day after Turkey’s Parliament voted to allow Sweden to join NATO.
content: President Biden sent a letter to four senior members of Congress on Wednesday urging them to quickly approve a $20 billion sale of F-16 fighter jets to Turkey, following the vote one day earlier by Turkey’s Parliament to allow Sweden to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, according to three U.S. officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Glen Powell at Sundance: ‘I’m Buzzing Right Now, Man!’
description: The star and co-writer of “Hit Man” heard that his film had wowed audiences, but because of the actors’ strike, he couldn’t see for himself until now.
content: Glen Powell doesn’t want for much these days, after co-starring in “Top Gun: Maverick” and watching his new film, the romantic comedy “Anyone but You,” cross $100 million at the worldwide box office. Still, for the past few months, there was one little thing he felt he had missed out on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Top Council Rejects Much of France’s Tough Immigration Law
description: The Constitutional Council, which reviews laws to ensure that they conform to the Constitution, struck down many measures that President Emmanuel Macron’s government had added under right-wing pressure.
content: France’s Constitutional Council struck down large chunks of a tough new immigration law on Thursday, issuing a widely expected ruling that many provisions added by President Emmanuel Macron’s government under right-wing pressure were unlawful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Israel Tries to Rebut Genocide Charge by Declassifying Cabinet Decisions
description: South Africa has accused Israel of committing genocide in Gaza. Israel’s legal team has challenged the charge by providing the court with secret orders made by Israel’s civilian and military leaders.
content: Israel has declassified more than 30 secret orders made by government and military leaders, which it says rebut the charge that it committed genocide in Gaza, and instead show Israeli efforts to diminish deaths among Palestinian civilians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: It’s Boom Times for Obamacare. Will They Last?
description: A record 21 million people signed up for marketplace plans for 2024, drawn in part by more generous federal subsidies. But the expanded subsidies are set to expire after next year.
content: Carley Calvi came to the second floor of a public library in suburban Milwaukee one morning this month without health insurance to cover the vertigo medication she needed. Worse, she said, was not having a doctor she trusted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: Bernard Arnault Names 2 More Sons to LVMH Board, Cementing Family Control
description: The move by France’s richest man extends a carefully planned succession strategy for the world’s biggest luxury company.
content: Bernard Arnault, the head of the LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton luxury goods empire, announced on Thursday that he had nominated two more of his children to sit on the company board, a move to cement his family’s control of Europe’s most valuable conglomerate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Mambar Pierrette’ Review: Cosmic Misfortunes
description: A gifted seamstress, played by the filmmaker Rosine Mbakam’s cousin, has to put out a string of fires in this rich portrait of Cameroonian womanhood.
content: Pierrette, a gifted seamstress and a mother of three, can’t seem to catch a break. After a hard day’s work at her humble shop in Douala, a busy city in Cameroon, she’s mugged by a motorcycle taxi driver. It’s also the rainy season and her home — and later her shop — is flooded overnight. It’s a foul time to be broke: The kids are heading back to school and their supplies aren’t cheap.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian MacDougall
title: ‘Every Politician Has Got to Have Somebody That’s the Hit Man’
description: A Republican state lawmaker devised a bribery scheme that ended in a trial and a death — and showed why corruption has become harder to prosecute.
content: Back in Ohio, Neil Clark went by many names: “most powerful lobbyist in Ohio,” “bully,” “superlobbyist,” “godfather of lobbyists.” Clark blamed his “dark Sicilian features and demeanor” for the last epithet, though it might also have had something to do with his fondness for Al Capone and the fact that his father was a soldier for the Cleveland Mafia. He wore each distinction with pride, the complimentary and derogatory alike. As he saw it, a lobbyist without enemies wasn’t much of a lobbyist. But the label Clark relished most of all was “prince of darkness.” It suited his sense of himself: a master of political devilry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: How Did These Strange Songs Hit No. 1?
description: Melanie’s “Brand New Key” is just one of many weird songs that somehow topped the Billboard charts.
content: When Melanie’s “Brand New Key” debuted in 1971, some people were confused. What did the singer, who died on Tuesday at 76, mean when she sang about having a brand-new pair of roller skates and someone else having a brand-new key?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What Students Are Saying About Learning to Write in the Age of A.I.
description: Does being able to write still matter when chatbots can do it for us? Teenagers weigh in on an essay from Opinion.
content: With artificial intelligence programs like ChatGPT that can generate prose for us, how much should we care about learning to write — and write well?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: In Winter, California Is for the Birds
description: Millions of birds migrate through the Golden State each year along the Pacific Flyway, which stretches from Alaska to the tip of South America.
content: Blackbirds flit between reeds jutting out of the marshy waters. A bald eagle perches in a tree, far above clusters of bobbing ducks. In a mesmerizing display, hundreds of snowy white geese take flight in an undulating swarm that mottles the gray sky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Maria Varenikova
title: Ukraine Searches for Answers on Russian Plane Crash
description: Moscow has accused Ukraine of downing the craft, which it says carried 65 Ukrainian P.O.W.s. The claims cannot be independently verified. Kyiv says Russia is exploiting the episode for propaganda.
content: Ukrainian officials pressed their efforts on Thursday to uncover the details of a deadly plane crash over the border in Russia, asking for patience from citizens while they investigated Moscow’s claims that Ukraine had shot down a Russian military aircraft carrying Ukrainian prisoners of war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman’s Case for Categorizing ‘Star Wars’ as Fantasy
description: The series has never been science fiction.
content: Michelle writes: Every time “Star Wars” is referenced in an article as science fiction, my husband rants about it. He says it’s fantasy. I’ve read him multiple definitions of science fiction, but he refuses to acknowledge that he’s wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Philippe Petit Returns to the High Wire at Age 74
description: Mr. Petit, who walked on a wire between the World Trade Center towers in 1974, will be performing at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. This morning we’ll find out where Philippe Petit, who walked on a wire between towers of the World Trade Center in 1974, plans to stroll next week. We’ll also find out why Mayor Eric Adams says New York City is “back from the brink.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess, Jonah E. Bromwich and William K. Rashbaum
title: Manhattan’s District Attorney Is Quietly Preparing for a Trump Trial
description: As prosecutors navigate calendars and appeals, Alvin L. Bragg may take the former president’s first criminal case to trial. He has said that covering up a hush-money payment was a fraud on voters.
content: Federal prosecutors have accused Donald J. Trump of plotting to subvert American democracy and mishandling nuclear secrets. But with those cases in limbo, state prosecutors in Manhattan are gearing up as though they will be the first to try the former president on criminal charges — for covering up a potential sex scandal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: A Stranger Bought a Set of Highly Personal Letters. Can I Call Him Out?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether the intimate details of one’s live should ever be sold by someone else.
content: I recently learned that my former husband’s stepmother put up her and his father’s estate at auction and included all of his keepsakes stored in their attic. This included a large collection of letters that my former husband received as a young man.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyce McFadden
title: Cheney Says Haley Should Stay in G.O.P. Primary Through Super Tuesday
description: Liz Cheney, the former congresswoman and an outspoken critic of former President Donald J. Trump, made the remarks in a podcast that will be released on Friday.
content: Former Representative Liz Cheney urged Nikki Haley to stay in the Republican primary race through Super Tuesday in an episode of “Pod Save America” that will be released on Friday. Ms. Cheney, an outspoken critic of former President Donald J. Trump, called his candidacy an “existential threat” to the nation and commended Ms. Haley for running against him, despite her long odds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Initial Ruling Expected in Genocide Case Against Israel: What to Know
description: The International Court of Justice is set to issue a decision on Friday that could call on Israel to stop its attacks in Gaza, although it has few means of enforcement.
content: The International Court of Justice is set to rule on Friday on South Africa’s demand that Israel immediately suspend its military offensive in Gaza. The ruling is an initial step in a wider case about whether Israel is committing genocide against Palestinians in the enclave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins
title: Poor Nikki, Poor Us
description: Nikki Haley is the only thing saving us from a full year of just Trump vs. Biden.
content: Two possible ways of looking at New Hampshire’s vote:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: Rihanna, Natalie Portman, Kylie Jenner, Zendaya and More Gallivant in Paris
description: Dresses, kisses, fan girls: the best celebrity moments at couture.
content: Haute couture is a celebration of artisanship — and one-upmanship — as the world’s top fashion houses gather in Paris to compete with one another and show off new designs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Dan Jones Turned to Fiction After Dinner With George R.R. Martin
description: “You’ve got to know when you’re onto a good thing,” says the prolific historian, British TV personality and author of “Wolves of Winter,” the second novel in his Hundred Years’ War trilogy.
content: What books are on your night stand?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Blackhawk
title: How ‘Killers of the Flower Moon’ Presses Up Against the Limits of Empathy
description: The movie offers clues about how a reckoning with American colonialism must begin.
content: “Can you find the wolves in this picture?” Ernest Burkhart asks, with the faltering pace of a child, from his home within the Osage Nation — lands only recently annexed by the United States to form Oklahoma. Ernest is seemingly reading both to himself and the audience of Martin Scorsese’s monumental “Killers of the Flower Moon,” which was nominated on Tuesday for 10 Academy Awards, including Best Picture. The film offers more than three hours of violent detail from a period in Native American history during the 1920s that newspapers called the “Reign of Terror” — a period that included the slaughter of dozens, possibly hundreds, of the Osage Nation’s citizens by non-Native people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher, Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman
title: Inside Trump’s Cutthroat Conquest of Iowa and New Hampshire
description: The former president’s victories in Iowa and New Hampshire were the product of a win-or-else ethos, a fractured opposition and his power to make the party stand for whatever he stands for.
content: Donald J. Trump’s campaign couldn’t have scripted the results in Iowa any better.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: Not Feeling Your Partner’s Name? Just Change It.
description: When Nikki Haley decided that her future husband, Bill, looked more like a Michael, a Michael he became. How unusual are name-change proclamations in the world of love?
content: Back when Nikki Haley, the last woman standing in the race for the Republican nomination, began dating her now-husband, she took a look at him and asked him what his name was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Fred Chappell, Admired but Unsung Writer of the South, Dies at 87
description: He wrote lyrical poetry and novels about life in North Carolina’s Appalachian Piedmont and was considered the South’s “premier contemporary person of letters.”
content: Fred Chappell, a poet, novelist and critic whose Faulknerian capacity to express universal themes of love, loss and memory through his evocations of North Carolina’s rural, mountainous west earned him a reputation as the South’s “premier contemporary person of letters,” in the words of one reviewer, died on Jan. 4 in Greensboro, N.C. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Azzopardi
title: ‘Lil Nas X: Long Live Montero’ Review: A Hip-Hop Trailblazer
description: The documentary, streaming on Max, follows the queer singer-rapper on the road and at home, but the best scenes by far are when he is onstage.
content: To watch the singer-rapper Lil Nas X in the documentary “Lil Nas X: Long Live Montero” is to witness a Black queer man embody a power that still feels very new.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: More Renters Than Ever Before Are Burdened by the Rent They Pay
description: A new Harvard report says 22.4 million households in the United States now spend more than 30 percent of their income in rent, with 12.1 million spending more than 50 percent.
content: Half of all renters in the United States spend more than 30 percent of their income on rent and utilities, more than at any other time in history, according to a new report by Harvard’s Joint Center for Housing Studies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Review: A Japanese ‘Boléro’? It’s a Spooky Ride of Revenge.
description: At Japan Society, “Nihon Buyo in the 21st Century,” a rare showcase in New York of this style of Japanese dance, forges a link between the past and present.
content: For better or worse, Ravel’s “Boléro,” with its churning swell of sound, has stirred the imagination of artists over time, among them the choreographer Maurice Béjart and the ice dancing team of Torvill and Dean. It even found a seductive partner, Bo Derek — along with her cornrows — in the Blake Edwards movie “10.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and Henrik Pryser Libell
title: A Norwegian Official Fought Plagiarism. Then She Was Caught Copying.
description: Norway’s higher education minister, Sandra Borch, resigned after admitting she “took text from other assignments without stating the sources,” in her master’s thesis.
content: As Norway’s higher education minister, Sandra Borch was responsible for making sure that students played by the rules. When one of those students was acquitted of the offense of plagiarism, Ms. Borch appealed, taking the case to the nation’s Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Six Bodies Found in Mojave Desert in Southern California
description: A call for a wellness check led the authorities to the gruesome discovery.
content: A call for a wellness check led the authorities in Southern California to make a gruesome discovery this week: They found six bodies at a remote crossroads in the Mojave Desert.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel and John Eligon
title: A Shocking Confession Upends the Case of a Fatal Fire in South Africa
description: Activists fear that one man’s sudden admission that he lit a crowded building ablaze to cover up a murder will let officials off the hook for failing to correct unsafe conditions there.
content: It was time, the witness said, to tell the whole truth about the awful things he had done.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien and Jonathan Swan
title: Haley Super PAC Says It Raised $50.1 Million, Eclipsing Trump
description: The figure for the second half of last year outstripped the $46 million that Donald Trump’s super PAC announced. But the Haley PAC has spent heavily, and it’s unclear how much is left.
content: The main super PAC backing Nikki Haley said Thursday that it had raised $50.1 million in the second half of 2023, a hefty sum that eclipses the amount brought in by the leading super PAC backing former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: The Victorious, Censorious, Malicious Donald Trump
description: He won New Hampshire — and showed us exactly who he is.
content: About an hour and a half after Donald Trump was declared the winner of the Republican primary in New Hampshire, he appeared onstage at a victory rally in Nashua, N.H., to bask in his accomplishment and bash lesser mortals. Bask-and-bash is his preferred M.O., an indulgence of the love he feels for himself and the contempt he feels for almost everybody else, and his bearing and remarks indeed had a familiar, compulsory ring. As Trump performances go, it was an unremarkable one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: When Will the European Central Bank Start Cutting Rates?
description: Interest rate cuts could start as soon as April, investors say. But the eurozone’s central bank, which held rates steady on Thursday, has said it will probably wait longer.
content: If what goes up must come down, then the urgent question on the minds of many in Europe is when will interest rates begin dropping? For months, rates have been set at the highest in the European Central Bank’s history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Iván Ulchur-Rota
title: When Chaos Erupted in Ecuador, Disinformation Followed
description: As violence broke out, an overwhelming flood of online disinformation further disoriented the nation.
content: One of the most terrifying spates of violence in Ecuador’s modern history began on Jan. 7. In quick succession, two jailed gang leaders escaped, riots broke out in the country’s main prisons and bombs exploded in several cities. A national television network was stormed by masked gunmen during a live broadcast. A little over a week later, the prosecutor investigating that attack was shot and killed. More than 20 people have been killed in the turmoil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘American Star’ Review: Armed and Vacationing
description: Ian McShane stars as an assassin killing time in the Canary Islands.
content: “American Star,” the latest film to showcase the travel benefits of being a professional killer, opens with Wilson (Ian McShane) arriving in Fuerteventura, one of the Canary Islands. After parking his rental car off the side of a desert road, he peeks in the trunk to find a photograph of his latest mark, who of course lives in a sleek, modernist home nearby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno and Karen Weise
title: Microsoft Cuts 1,900 Jobs in Its Video Game Division
description: The reductions come three months after the tech giant completed its $69 billion acquisition of Activision Blizzard.
content: Microsoft said Thursday that it would eliminate 1,900 roles in its video game division, including at Activision Blizzard, which it acquired for $69 billion three months ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Tesla Tumbles as Growth Slows
description: Shares in Elon Musk’s electric vehicle maker fell sharply after the company delivered lackluster quarterly results and declined to give full-year guidance.
content: Elon Musk and Tesla shareholders are at a crossroads.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Mail 3 Days a Week? Idea Meets Resistance in Britain.
description: Letter volumes have halved since 2011. Without significant changes, the beleaguered Royal Mail services will become “out of date,” according to a report.
content: Britain’s postal service could consider cutting deliveries to five days a week, or even three, from six, the country’s regulator said on Wednesday, drawing resistance from lawmakers and businesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Business Insider Laying Off 8% of Staff
description: In an internal note about the job cuts, the company’s chief executive cited its plan to shift focus solely to news coverage of business, tech and innovation.
content: Business Insider said on Thursday that it was laying off 8 percent of its staff, the latest in a wave of sharp job cuts in the media industry this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Alan Feuer
title: Trump’s ‘Al Capone’ Strategy Carries Risks in November
description: Highlighting his own trials could backfire on Trump.
content: Two days after his victory in the New Hampshire primary, Donald Trump was back in court today, testifying in the defamation case brought against him in New York by E. Jean Carroll, the writer who has accused him of raping her in a department store dressing room in the 1990s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: How Often Is Taylor Swift Actually Shown at N.F.L. Games?
description: A romance between the pop star and Travis Kelce has dominated social media, but TV broadcasts are focusing on it less than many seem to think.
content: As Taylor Swift’s N.F.L. adventure began in earnest at a Kansas City Chiefs game against the Chicago Bears on Sept. 24, the reaction of the Fox broadcast crew — and much of the N.F.L. world in general — was summed up by Erin Andrews, a veteran sideline reporter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: A New Wave of Nicotine Products Comes Under Scrutiny
description: Senator Chuck Schumer has called for a crackdown on ZYN, a trendy brand of nicotine pouches.
content: Senator Chuck Schumer called this week for a crackdown on ZYN, a nicotine pouch that has become increasingly popular in the United States, alongside the rise of so-called Zynfluencers who tout the product online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh and Stuart A. Thompson
title: He Died in a Tragic Accident. Why Did the Internet Say He Was Murdered?
description: Within a day of the death of Matthew Sachman, 19, on New York City subway tracks, so-called obituary pirates had flooded search results with false information.
content: It was the kind of tragic accident that reverberates through a community: a first-year college student, out late in New York City on New Year’s Eve, falls onto the subway tracks and is killed by an oncoming train.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: R.N.C. Says It Looks Like Michigan G.O.P. Leader Was ‘Properly Removed’
description: Kristina Karamo, the state party’s embattled chairwoman, is disputing the legality of her ouster earlier this month by Republican leaders.
content: Lawyers for the Republican National Committee say it looks like Kristina Karamo was “properly removed” as chairwoman of the Michigan Republican Party earlier this month, but Ms. Karamo and her newly-elected replacement both maintain that they are in charge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles
title: An Unlikely New Threat to Haiti’s Stability: An Armed Environmental Group
description: The country’s political crisis grew more volatile this week after an armed environmental brigade allied with a former coup leader began demanding the prime minister’s ouster.
content: In Haiti, as the number of murders soar and kidnappings rise, even the police are fleeing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Betts and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: The Alabama Execution Case: What We Know
description: Kenneth Eugene Smith was put to death by nitrogen gas on Thursday night, the first time the method was used in capital punishment in the U.S.
content: Alabama carried out on Thursday the first execution using nitrogen gas in the United States, an untested method that was the subject of debate before it was used. The inmate, Kenneth Smith, was pronounced dead at 8:25 p.m. Central time at the William C. Holman Correctional Facility in Atmore, Ala., after the U.S. Supreme Court denied an appeal to stay the execution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Qatar Expresses Anger Over Netanyahu’s Leaked Criticism
description: In a recording that aired on Israeli television, a voice that appears to be Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s called Qatar’s role as a mediator “problematic” because of its relationship to Hamas.
content: Qatar has accused Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of hurting efforts to secure the release of hostages after a leaked recording appeared to catch the Israeli leader criticizing the country, which has been a key mediator in talks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: Where Can Gen Z Buy a Home?
description: Older members of the generation are early in their careers, and they face increases in inflation, home prices and interest rates.
content: If Gen Z can’t afford the rent, how are they ever going to buy a home?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Trump Says Haley Donors Will Be ‘Barred From the MAGA Camp’
description: Far from trying to unite Republicans as he seeks to cast himself as their inevitable nominee, Donald Trump threatened supporters of his last major primary rival, Nikki Haley.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump essentially threatened Nikki Haley’s donors with excommunication from his political movement on Wednesday night, declaring that he would refuse contributions from anyone who donated to her primary campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: C.J. Box Isn’t Afraid to Wrangle With Issues Close to Home
description: The creator of two mystery series has the latitude — and the attitude — to address matters other writers wouldn’t touch with a 10-foot pole.
content: “I’m looking at the ridge outside my window,” C.J. Box said in a phone interview. “There’s one antelope going over the top to the other side.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Met Opera Taps Its Endowment Again to Weather Downturn
description: The company has withdrawn nearly $40 million in additional funds from its endowment to cover expenses, but sees signs it may be emerging from its post-pandemic woes.
content: The Metropolitan Opera, still reeling from the disruption brought by the pandemic, said on Thursday that it had withdrawn nearly $40 million in additional emergency funds from its endowment as it works to survive one of the most trying periods in its 141-year history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Film Club: ‘How to Protect Millions of Workers Without a Union’
description: In a Times Opinion video, Jeff Seal, a journalist and comedian, makes a colorful case that there’s more than one way for workers to organize. Is he convincing?
content: Unions have recently scored big victories in the auto industry and Hollywood. However, the percentage of workers who belong to a union plunged to its lowest level on record in 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong and Julian E. Barnes
title: U.S. Is Watching North Korea for Signs of Lethal Military Action
description: A shift by Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, toward open hostility against South Korea is alarming but does not indicate he is about to start a full-scale war, officials say.
content: North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, could take some form of lethal military action against South Korea in the coming months after having shifted to a policy of open hostility, U.S. officials say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Abbie VanSickle
title: Alabama Carries Out First U.S. Execution by Nitrogen
description: The state executed Kenneth Smith on Thursday using the untested method of nitrogen hypoxia after the Supreme Court declined to intervene.
content: Alabama carried out the first American execution using nitrogen gas on Thursday evening, killing a convicted murderer whose jury had voted to spare his life and opening a new frontier in how states execute death row prisoners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: ‘No Time to Go Wobbly’: Why Britain Is Lobbying U.S. Republicans on Ukraine
description: The U.K., often a wingman to the United States in defense, is pushing its ally to stand firm against President Vladimir V. Putin, amid fears that Russia poses an existential threat to Europe.
content: When David Cameron, Britain’s foreign secretary and onetime prime minister, visited Washington last month, he took time out to press the case for backing Ukraine with Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, the far-right Georgia Republican who stridently opposes further American military aid to the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano and Tripp Mickle
title: Apple Overhauls App Store in Europe, in Response to New Digital Law
description: An E.U. law taking effect in March forced Apple to loosen its grip on the App Store, changes it had long resisted.
content: Since Apple introduced the App Store in 2008, it has tightly controlled the apps and services allowed on iPhones and iPads, giving the company an iron grip on one of the digital economy’s most valuable storefronts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: Feeling Stuck? Here Are 5 Ways to Jumpstart Your Life.
description: Mental health experts suggest exercises to knock down the internal roadblocks that are causing burnout and holding you back.
content: From the outside, it looked as though Adam Alter was gliding along.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: After Its Big Setback, New Jersey Awards 2 Offshore Wind Contracts
description: The awards came just three months after a developer backed out of two contracts to supply power to New Jersey.
content: New Jersey awarded two additional contracts for electricity from offshore wind farms on Wednesday, moving forward with the state’s ambitious plans to turn to the Atlantic Ocean for power after a surprising blow to them last year.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Word of the Day: hydrologic
description: This word has appeared in seven articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?

author: By Jamal Michel
title: My Mosque Preached Damnation, but Grand Theft Auto Offered Thrills
description: The sprawling and violent world of Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas was a complicated indulgence for a Black Muslim teenager.
content: My mother had no idea I was picking up sex workers. My sex appeal wasn’t very high, but I figured the paint job of my lowrider was attractive enough for me to get lucky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikita Richardson
title: A Hello, a Return and a Chicken Potpie
description: Nikita Richardson is back with recommendations for a funky breakfast sandwich at an all-day restaurant and more.
content: Fancy seeing you here. If you’ve only started reading “Where to Eat” in the last four months, then you may not know me: I’m Nikita Richardson, and I’m freshly returned from a stint on The Times’s Live team covering breaking news. (Thank you so much to Pete Wells for covering for me while I was away. If you’d like him to keep appearing in your inbox, be sure to subscribe to the Restaurant Review newsletter so you can keep up with his way-more-official eating adventures.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Visiting the Most Important Company in the World
description: Replicating the chipmaking power of T.S.M.C. in the United States will be much harder than Americans realize.
content: “If China takes Taiwan, they will turn the world off, potentially,” Donald Trump told Fox News recently, apparently referring to a potential seizure of one company that is central to, well, pretty much everything. Indeed, it’s arguably the most important company in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and César Rodríguez
title: She Looked for Her Missing Brother. Now, People Are Looking for Her.
description: The violent abduction of volunteer searcher Lorenza Cano is yet another fresh wound for the hundreds of mothers looking for Mexico’s missing.
content: Only a few torn pieces of the crime scene tape around Lorenza Cano’s house are left. The shards of glass from the front door are gone. So are the bullet casings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: Nitrogen Hypoxia: What to Know About This New Method of Execution
description: Alabama will be the first state to use nitrogen in an execution. If it goes smoothly, other states are likely to follow.
content: The planned execution of a death row inmate by the state of Alabama on Thursday evening will be carried out by a procedure that has never been used for capital punishment in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: A Huge Win for Activists Puts Climate on the 2024 Agenda
description: The Biden administration will examine how a natural gas mega-project will impact the climate.
content: This is just what the climate activists wanted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: What to Watch This Weekend: Something Hot
description: Our TV critic recommends a wild and wide-ranging documentary series about the world of hot pepper enthusiasts.
content: Documentaries about niche subcultures abound: dog dancing, science fairs, yo-yos. Few if any include as much on-screen vomiting as the Hulu series “Superhot: The Spicy World of Pepper People,” but then, few cover quite as much ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Rutenberg and Kate Conger
title: Elon Musk Is Spreading Election Misinformation, but X’s Fact Checkers Are Long Gone
description: Civil rights lawyers and Democrats are sounding alarms about Mr. Musk’s claims about voting. The Biden campaign called his posts “profoundly irresponsible.”
content: In the spring of 2020, when President Donald J. Trump wrote messages on Twitter warning that increased reliance on mail-in ballots would lead to a “rigged election,” the platform ran a corrective, debunking his claims.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Rojas
title: That Spotify Daylist That Really ‘Gets’ You? It Was Written by A.I.
description: The music-streaming platform’s new “daylist” feature serves users three personalized playlists a day, with titles ranging from quirky to bewildering.
content: Have your Sunday scaries ever given way to a “Nervous Ocean Monday Morning”? Does the weekend truly begin on Friday, or on a “Wild and Free Chaotic Thursday Afternoon”? How should one dress for a “Paranormal Dark Cabaret Evening”?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Edward E. Crutchfield, 82, Dies; Banker’s Deals Reshaped the Industry
description: He built a small Southern bank into a regional powerhouse, helping to turn Charlotte, N.C., into a national financial hub.
content: Edward E. Crutchfield, a banker who grew a small North Carolina bank into one of the nation’s largest through a deal-making spree that earned him the nickname “Fast Eddie” and helped establish Charlotte as a national financial hub, died on Jan. 2 at his home in Vero Beach, Fla. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Classical Music Albums You Can Listen to Right Now
description: Igor Levit’s response to tragedy, Ethan Iverson’s first piano sonata and a personal recording by Gidon Kremer are among the highlights.
content: Music doesn’t have the power to end wars. Peace, said Daniel Barenboim, whose West-Eastern Divan Orchestra brings together Israeli and Palestinian artists, “needs something else.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Six-Day Strike Halts Most German Trains
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, January 25, 2024.
content: “I try to use the train for environmental reasons. But then they really should function.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Friday Briefing: Will North Korea Attack?
description: Plus, when A.I. generates copyrighted images.
content: North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, could take some form of lethal military action against South Korea in the coming months after having shifted his policy to one of open hostility, U.S. officials say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher, Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan
title: Trump Ally Withdraws Plan for a G.O.P. Resolution to Move Past Haley
description: David Bossie, an R.N.C. committeeman, had proposed a draft resolution declaring Donald Trump “our presumptive 2024 nominee” for president, though it would have had no practical effect on primaries.
content: One of Donald J. Trump’s key allies inside the Republican National Committee withdrew a planned resolution to try to force the party’s official body to say that the G.O.P. presidential nominating contest is effectively over, even though only two states have voted and Nikki Haley has vowed to continue her campaign against the dominant front-runner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Haley Looks to Fight on Home Turf, Which Her Rival Claims as Trump Country
description: Nikki Haley, facing growing doubts and pressure to drop out, has winnowed the race to a one-on-one contest and is looking to make her case in South Carolina.
content: A combative Nikki Haley brought her presidential campaign back to South Carolina on Wednesday after a disappointing defeat the night before in New Hampshire, and told a boisterous crowd in a cavernous ballroom in North Charleston that she would fight Donald J. Trump for the Republican nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon, Caitlin O'Keefe and Anna Foley
title: The ‘People’s President’ vs. the Donor Class
description: There’s a war raging inside the Republican Party. And the matchup between Donald Trump and Nikki Haley lays it bare.
content: Donald Trump’s victory over Nikki Haley in the New Hampshire primary made two things clear: The MAGA wing of the G.O.P. is ready for his coronation, while anti-Trump Republicans believe the race is far from over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Rep. Bowman Faulted in Capitol False Alarm, but Spared Inquiry
description: The House’s Office of Congressional Ethics found that Jamaal Bowman’s explanation for pulling a House fire alarm last September was “less than credible.”
content: The House Ethics Committee on Thursday dropped its investigation into Representative Jamaal Bowman of New York for pulling a House fire alarm, but released a report that found his explanations “less than credible and otherwise misleading.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Jan. 31, 2024
description: How are the chances of being admitted to an elite college affected by income and by being a legacy applicant?
content: This graph was previously published in The New York Times. It is based on the findings of a study of college applicants to 12 highly selective colleges: the Ivy League (Brown, Columbia, Cornell, Dartmouth, Harvard, Princeton, University of Pennsylvania, and Yale), plus Duke, M.I.T., the University of Chicago and Stanford. The anonymous data is from the years 1999 to 2015.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabino Iglesias
title: 4 New Horror Novels That Are as Fresh as They Are Terrifying
description: New books by Emily Ruth Verona, Jenny Kiefer, Christopher Golden and Tlotlo Tsamaase riff on classic tropes and deliver thrilling scares.
content: Emily Ruth Verona’s MIDNIGHT ON BEACON STREET (Harper Perennial, 195 pp., paperback, $17.99) is a lot of things. It’s a taut thriller about a babysitter and two kids surviving one weird night. It’s a celebration of classic horror movies. It’s a creepy narrative that involves a ghost and late night home break-ins. And, most important, it’s a lot of fun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Cooking
title: Comfort Cooking Beyond Casseroles
description: Chicken mei fun, plump roasted peppers and a plate of bangers and mash are effortless victories.
content: We’ve been in comfort-cooking mode for a while now, and this last stretch of January really has us reaching for recipes that soothe and nourish. Soups and stews, yes, and generous casseroles, but also dishes that feel like effortless victories, filling the home with wonderful smells and making us do that satisfied, mmm-shrugging thing with our shoulders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Taking on Trump, Biden Promotes ‘Infrastructure Decade’ in Wisconsin
description: The president made the trip to promote a $1 billion infrastructure project, contrasting his performance with the chaotic “Infrastructure Week” plans of former President Donald J. Trump.
content: Consumer confidence is up. Fears of a recession are abating. The economy is growing. And a corroded bridge in Wisconsin is receiving more funding.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Inflation Worries and Snickers Bars
description: Readers discuss an essay that argued their worries were irrational. Also: Tuning Donald Trump out; Mayor Adams’s veto; a U.S.-Canada wall; a refuge from politics.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Journalists at New York Daily News Walk Off Job for a Day
description: Newsroom workers at The Daily News Union, which formed in 2021, are in negotiations for their first contract.
content: Journalists at The New York Daily News walked off the job on Thursday for the first time in more than three decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Asher Elbein
title: Do Not Fear the Robo-Dinosaur, Learn From It
description: Scientists built a working model of an early winged dinosaur to test a hypothesis about how the appendages evolved.
content: The origin of bird wings has long presented a puzzle to paleontologists: Why did these structures develop in the age of the dinosaurs? And what were some of the earliest wings used for, if not for flight?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tripp Mickle and Cade Metz
title: Cruise Says Hostility to Regulators Led to Grounding of Its Autonomous Cars
description: A law firm’s review found that executives had failed to fully explain an October crash, which the Justice Department is also investigating.
content: Cruise, the driverless car subsidiary of General Motors, said in a report on Thursday that an adversarial approach taken by its top executives toward regulators had led to a cascade of events that ended with a nationwide suspension of Cruise’s fleet and investigations by California and federal authorities, including the Justice Department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John White, Larissa Anderson, Kyle Buchanan and Daniel Ramirez
title: 2024 Oscar Nominations
description: Our Awards Season reporter helps us sift through the snubs and surprises of this year’s awards.
content: Pop culture reporter Kyle Buchanan has been covering the long campaign leading up to the Oscar nominations. He helps make sense of who is being recognized and who’s been left behind for the most prestigious award in the film industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: Will a New Monument for Those Enslaved by France Heal or Divide?
description: The memorial will list the names of those freed in 1848, a design some say does more to glorify France for abolition than to atone for slavery itself.
content: As the color drained from the sky, a group gathered before the white-stoned basilica of St. Denis, where dozens of French kings are buried, to pay homage to their ancestors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes, Hiba Yazbek, Aaron Boxerman and Roni Caryn Rabin
title: U.S., Sensing Opportunity, Makes New Push for Gaza Cease-Fire
description: William Burns, the C.I.A. director, planned to meet Israeli, Egyptian and Qatari officials in Europe to try to secure a deal to release the Hamas hostages and a pause in the combat.
content: William J. Burns, the C.I.A. director, plans to travel to Europe to meet with senior Israeli, Egyptian and Qatari officials, in a sign the United States is pushing to secure a deal to release the hostages being held in the Gaza Strip and broker a prolonged cease-fire, according to U.S. officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang and Hisako Ueno
title: Japan Explains How It Made an Upside-Down Moon Landing
description: The SLIM spacecraft survived its trip to the surface, but ended up pointing in a direction that now limits the duration of its mission.
content: Japan became the fifth nation to land on the moon on Saturday, but its spacecraft ended up in an awkward position, with its engine nozzle pointed up toward space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Fauzia
title: The Sex-Obsessed Marsupials That Will Sleep When They’re Dead
description: Scientists find that male antechinuses, rodent-like animals from Australia, will forgo sleep for sex during their breeding season, after which they die.
content: Scurrying along the dense brush of coastal woodlands and forests, the small, mouselike antechinus appears more unassuming than many of Australia’s marsupials. But for the three weeks of their breeding season, the males transform into absolute sex-obsessed lotharios.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’ Book Recommendations (2023)
description: Readings that the podcast’s guests say shaped their thinking.
content: “The Ezra Klein Show” explores ideas with some of today’s most dynamic thinkers. We cover politics, culture, history, philosophy, psychology, technology and more. The topics are wide-ranging, but every episode ends with Ezra asking his guest (or guests) to recommend a few books that have shaped their thinking. Below is a list of all the books recommended on the show in 2023, in reverse-chronological order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Emma Goldberg, Sydney Harper, Will Reid, Mooj Zadie, Patricia Willens, Dan Powell, Diane Wong, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano and Alyssa Moxley
title: The Hybrid Worker Malaise
description: Tens of millions of Americans now mix office and remote work. What challenges does this new model bring?
content: The era of hybrid work has spawned a new kind of office culture — one that has left many workers less connected and less happy than they have ever been.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Needelman
title: In a New Cannabis Landscape, a Navy Veteran Battles for Racial Equity
description: Wanda James is on a mission to empower entrepreneurs from communities harmed by racial disparities in marijuana arrests.
content: “Transforming Spaces” is a series about women driving change in sometimes unexpected places.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Louisiana and Texas Face Flooding, With More Rain Expected Across the South
description: Parts of the South will see additional rain on Thursday after days of soaking rain, meteorologists said, raising concerns of flash flooding.
content: Heavy downpours over parts of Louisiana and Texas this week have caused significant flooding, meteorologists and officials said, and more rain is forecast to soak the region through the end of the week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Bill Hayes, Enduring Soap Star With a ‘Davy Crockett’ Hit, Is Dead at 98
description: He logged more than 2,000 episodes on “Days of Our Lives” and rode the Crockett craze to a hit single in 1955.
content: Bill Hayes, an actor and singer whose 2,141 episodes of “Days of Our Lives” over five and a half decades constituted the daytime drama version of an ultramarathon, and whose top-selling 1955 single, “The Ballad of Davy Crockett,” remains seared into the memories of the baby boom generation, died on Jan. 12 at his home in Studio City, Calif. He was 98.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon and Victoria Kim
title: For Second Time This Month, a Politician Is Attacked in South Korea
description: Bae Hyunjin, of the country’s governing party, was assaulted in Seoul and taken to a hospital. The attack came three weeks after another politician was stabbed.
content: A person struck a South Korean lawmaker in the head with a blunt object in Seoul on Thursday, causing injuries that were not life-threatening, according to her staff and physicians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: U.S. Economy Grew at 3.3% Rate in Latest Quarter
description: The increase in gross domestic product, while slower than in the previous period, showed the resilience of the recovery from the pandemic’s upheaval.
content: The U.S. economy continued to grow at a healthy pace at the end of 2023, capping a year in which unemployment remained low, inflation cooled and a widely predicted recession never materialized.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: Our recommended books this week include two surveys of modern science: one by an astrophysicist explaining the weirder aspects of her field, the other by a science reporter connecting the dots between natural phenomena and her own life. Also up, the biography of a celebrated war correspondent, a serious look at the business of comedy and a volume of essays that Christopher Hitchens wrote for The London Review of Books over the years. In fiction, we recommend a novel of friendship among exiles and a story collection by a Canadian master of the form, along with a romance novel and a buzzy fiction debut by the poet Kaveh Akbar. Happy reading. — Gregory Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember and Santul Nerkar
title: Airlines Hoping for More Boeing Jets Could Be Waiting Awhile
description: The Federal Aviation Administration’s decision to limit Boeing’s production of 737 Max planes could hurt airlines that are struggling to buy enough new aircraft.
content: Boeing hoped 2024 would be the year it would significantly increase production of its popular Max jets. But less than a month into the year, the company is struggling to reassure airline customers that it will still be able to deliver on its promises.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Thursday Briefing
description: A military plane crash near the Russian border.
content: A large Russian military transport plane crashed yesterday near the border with Ukraine, killing the 65 Ukrainian prisoners of war, six crew members and three other people on board, the Russian Defense Ministry said, accusing Ukraine of shooting down the plane with missiles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu and Sheera Frenkel
title: From Opposite Sides of War, a Hunt for Elusive Facts
description: The Israel-Hamas conflict has produced a prodigious amount of disinformation, putting people who fact-check claims — especially those who live in the region — back on their heels.
content: In the frantic early hours of Oct. 7, amid wailing sirens and word of gunfights along Israel’s southern border, Achiya Schatz rushed with his toddler and heavily pregnant wife into a bomb shelter near Tel Aviv.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bernard Mokam
title: A College Essay, Revisited Over 10 Years Later
description: After affirmative action fell, students began rewriting their application essays to emphasize race. The moment led a reporter and former essay coach to reflect on the power of the personal statement.
content: The college application essay challenges high school students to distill a formative experience in around 650 words. It may be the first time students write about themselves, the first time they are compelled to meditate on the moments that have shaped who they are, and commit those reflections into words.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: The Looming Contest Between Two Presidents and Two Americas
description: The general election matchup that seems likely between President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump is about fundamentally disparate visions of the nation.
content: Each of them has sat behind the Resolute Desk in the Oval Office, signed bills into law, appointed judges, bartered with foreign leaders and ordered the armed forces into combat. They both know what it is like to be the most powerful person on the planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Trump Strengthens Grip on Capitol Hill as He Presses Toward Nomination
description: The former president’s opposition has all but killed the prospects for a bipartisan border deal, reflecting how his influence in Congress has grown as he gains ground in the Republican primary.
content: For months, Senate Republicans have been working with Democrats on a deal they have described as a once-in-a-generation opportunity for a conservative border security bill, and for weeks, they have hinted that they are tantalizingly close to an agreement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jori Finkel
title: A Beacon of Modern Architecture Lands in the Desert
description: The Aluminaire House drew crowds, and ridicule, in 1931. After several moves and a brush with demolition, it has found a home in Southern California.
content: The Aluminaire House, one of the earliest and edgiest examples of the International Style of modernist architecture in America, was never meant to withstand a harsh desert climate. Originally it wasn’t even designed to be outside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Scheduled to Fly on a Boeing Max 9? Here Are Your Options.
description: With inspection guidelines set for the grounded planes, airlines could start flying the 737 Max 9 later this week. Here’s what travelers should know.
content: After a portion of an Alaska Airlines Boeing 737 Max 9 jetliner’s fuselage blew out in midair minutes after taking off from Portland, Ore., on Jan. 5, the Federal Aviation Administration grounded about 170 Max 9 planes, causing airlines that rely heavily on the aircraft to cancel thousands of flights and inconveniencing many passengers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: A Titanic Geopolitical Struggle Is Underway
description: This is no ordinary moment in world affairs.
content: There are many ways to explain the two biggest conflicts in the world today, but my own shorthand has been that Ukraine wants to join the West and Israel wants to join the Arab East — and Russia, with Iran’s help, is trying to stop the first, and Iran and Hamas are trying to stop the second.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: Never Trumpers Never Had a Chance
description: Animosity proved stronger than character or ideology.
content: The Republican presidential primary is all but over. Even if Nikki Haley stays in the race, it’s hard to see her winning a single primary, including the one in her home state of South Carolina next month. Even though Haley received an impressive 43 percent of the New Hampshire vote, her electoral reality is grim. According to the most recent FiveThirtyEight polling averages, she trails Donald Trump by more than 56 points nationally and by 37 points in South Carolina.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: McConnell Casts Doubt on Border Deal, Saying Trump Opposition May Sink It
description: The minority leader privately told Republicans that the former president had put his party “in a quandary,” casting further doubt on the deal’s chances and the fate of Ukraine aid that the G.O.P. has tied to it.
content: The emerging bipartisan border deal is hitting fresh snags among Republicans on Capitol Hill because of the opposition of former President Donald J. Trump, who is closing in on his party’s presidential nomination at a critical time for the agreement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: Gypsy Rose Blanchard and the Big Shift in True Crime
description: Not long ago, true crime storytellers had little in the way of first-person footage captured in real time to rely on. Now, as much of our daily lives are documented, the genre is transforming.
content: There’s a moment near the end of the 2017 documentary “Mommy Dead and Dearest” where Gypsy Rose Blanchard is filming her boyfriend at the time, Nicholas Godejohn, as he lies nude in a hotel room bed. A day earlier, Godejohn had stabbed to death Gypsy’s mother, Dee Dee Blanchard. The killing was part of a plot the couple hatched to free Gypsy, who was then 23, from her mother’s grip so they could be together. In the short video, we hear Gypsy make a playful sexual comment amid her copious, distinctive giggling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Plans for Gaza’s ‘Day After’ Seem Ever Distant
description: The very idea that there will be a clear line between war and peace is misleading, given the politics, security needs and anxieties of all sides.
content: As the war in Gaza grinds on, there is increasing talk of some “day after” formula for the broken territory. But that notion is an ephemeral one — there is not going to be a bright line between war and peace in Gaza, even if some sort of negotiated settlement is reached.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiba Yazbek, Ameera Harouda and Michael Levenson
title: U.N. Shelter in Besieged Khan Younis Is Struck, and at Least 9 Die
description: United Nations officials said a building that was being used as a shelter by about 800 people had been “clearly marked” as one of their facilities. Israel denied responsibility.
content: Israeli forces pushed deeper into southern Gaza’s largest city on Wednesday, surrounding two major hospitals where thousands of people were seeking safety as a strike on a United Nations shelter killed at least nine people, according to U.N. officials and local health officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Show of Hands
description: Sam Ezersky raises the temperature in his grid.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Pictures of Ghosts’ Review: Layers of Love and Memory
description: The Brazilian director Kleber Mendonça Filho draws on fact and fiction in this image-rich documentary that moves fast and far, but always returns home.
content: Early in “Pictures of Ghosts,” an exhilarating documentary about specters onscreen and off, the Brazilian director Kleber Mendonça Filho, pulls out a VHS tape. It’s of a 1981 TV interview with his mother, Joselice, a historian who died at age 54. In close-up, she discusses gathering information left out of history, an approach that her son has embraced here. After the tape abruptly cuts off, he says in voice-over, “it may seem like I’m discussing methodology” — as if speaking now both for his mother and for himself — “but I’m talking about love.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Institutions Are (Quietly) Taking Sackler Money
description: Financial accounts show that the Sackler Trust, a British nonprofit that the family set up, pledged over $6 million in 2022. But few organizations will admit to taking it.
content: When arts organizations began shunning the Sackler family over its role in the U.S. opioid crisis, it wasn’t just American institutions that cut ties. Museums in Britain that had accepted Sackler largess were among the first to take action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Supreme Court Declines to Stop Nitrogen Execution in Alabama
description: Both the Supreme Court and a federal appeals court denied stays sought by Kenneth Smith, who is scheduled to die on Thursday in the nation’s first nitrogen gas execution.
content: The U.S. Supreme Court and a federal appeals court each declined on Wednesday to intervene to stop Alabama from conducting the nation’s first-ever execution by nitrogen gas, putting the state on track to use the novel method to kill a death row prisoner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: N.S.A. Buys Americans’ Internet Data Without Warrants, Letter Says
description: The disclosure comes amid congressional scrutiny and a Federal Trade Commission crackdown on commercial data brokers.
content: The National Security Agency buys certain logs related to Americans’ domestic internet activities from commercial data brokers, according to an unclassified letter by the agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Benjamin Weiser
title: In Trump’s Defamation Trial, the Nine Most Important People Are Enigmas
description: The identities of the jurors deciding how much the former president will pay E. Jean Carroll are secret, thanks to a judge’s order.
content: Attorneys for E. Jean Carroll and Donald J. Trump, pitted against each other in a civil defamation trial in Manhattan, know little about the nine people considering her claim for millions of dollars in damages against the former president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Chaundler
title: Luis Rubiales, Ex-Chief of Spanish Soccer, to Face Trial Over World Cup Kiss
description: The ruling by a National Court judge resulted from a pretrial inquiry into an unsolicited kiss that set off a widespread debate about sexism in Spanish women’s soccer.
content: Luis Rubiales, Spain’s onetime soccer chief, is due to be tried over his nonconsensual kiss of a star player during the Women’s World Cup medal ceremony last summer after a judge recommended on Thursday that he face a court’s judgment in a high-profile case that has upended the sport in Spain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: The U.S. Economy Continues to Defy Expectations
description: Also, the U.S. said North Korean threats should be taken seriously. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
content: The American economy grew at a healthy pace through the end of 2023, according to government data released today. Unemployment remained low, inflation continued to cool and gross domestic product rose at a 3.3 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter, beating forecasters’ expectations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Yellen, Criticizing Trump, Says Biden’s Economy Has Delivered Gains
description: The Treasury Secretary acknowledged that consumer prices, which have weighed on economic sentiment, continue to be too high.
content: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen defended the Biden administration’s economic agenda on Thursday, drawing sharp contrasts with the policies of the Trump administration as President Biden begins to make the general election argument that he has been a stronger steward of the economy than his predecessor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Sweden’s Leader Says He Will Meet With Orban to Advance NATO Bid
description: The Hungarian leader, Viktor Orban, invited his Swedish counterpart to Budapest for talks. Hungary is the last country to vote to accept Sweden’s bid to join NATO after Turkey’s Parliament did so this week.
content: Bowing to a Hungarian demand for negotiations over the expansion of NATO, the prime minister of Sweden on Thursday agreed to hold talks with Hungary’s leader, Viktor Orban, the last obstacle blocking the Nordic nation’s admission to the military alliance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Sums Up the New Hampshire Primary
description: Jimmy Kimmel joked that Donald Trump beat Nikki Haley by 11 points and that he’s “also leading Haley by double digits in felony charges, 91 to zero.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: Here Comes the Broccoli
description: Stewed with farro, puréed into pesto, sizzled with dates and seared with halloumi.
content: In the doldrums of January, it can feel most natural to eat like the weather: beige foods inside to match the shades of taupe outside. But inevitably, when that little voice inside my head cries out for something green, there is one vegetable that comes to mind first: broccoli.

author: By Caitie Kelly
title: A Red Velvet Bistro in an Istanbul Villa
description: Plus: jewelry handmade with Roman coins, vintage Estée Lauder fragrances and more recommendations from T Magazine.
content: During the 49 years that Estée Lauder worked at her namesake company, she oversaw the creation of a dozen scents and encouraged women to create fragrance “wardrobes” tailored to every occasion and mood. The brand’s Legacy Collection, which comes out on Feb. 1, revives five of Lauder’s creations with the help of Frédéric Malle (whose perfume brand was acquired by the Estée Lauder Companies in 2015) and the perfumers Anne Flipo, Carlos Benaïm and Bruno Jovanovic, all of whom have worked with Malle on previous fragrances. During an interview inside Lauder’s well-preserved office near Central Park, Malle explained how he retooled the scents using more modern fragrance-making techniques. He noted that, in Lauder’s day, perfumers combined base scents that were “like premixed mini-perfumes” to create a final fragrance. “They contained things that weren’t necessary and created background noise,” Malle said. To update the formulas, any nonessential ingredients in those bases were stripped away — “it’s like cleaning up,” he said. The new collection has notes that range from fresh and herbaceous to musky and sweet. Azurée, initially released in 1969, evokes dry Mediterranean shores with herby notes like basil and tarragon as well as jasmine, spicy cardamom, bergamot, and cumin, which Malle amplified in his edition. For White Linen, a classic floral bouquet of rose and jasmine, Malle used pure labdanum, an ambery resin from the rockrose plant, which wasn’t available when the scent debuted in 1978. Knowing, a seductive scent from 1988, “contained a little bit of the Muzak of the ’80s,” Malle said. The modernized version is a fruity chypre with raspberries, black currant, rose and patchouli. The overall goal of the collection, Malle said, “is to revive this work and show how good Mrs. Lauder was.” The Legacy Collection is available from Feb. 1, $280, esteelauder.com.
